{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3387333,"name":"","username":"Narnillian","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/6a8cbe/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-16T23:24:08.751Z","cooked":"

We are currently using the SDS MK4i swerve modules, but we donâ€™t want to spend $100 to replace an encoder. AndyMark has a REV Through Bore Encoder to SDS MK4i Adapter, which seems like a cheap and easy replacement. Is this product reliable and sufficient for swerve needs? If this doesnâ€™t work we are also considering the Helium Canandcoders and TTB Thrifty Encoders.

I didnâ€™t know this existed either. Interesting.

andymark.com

REV Through Bore Encoder to SDS MK4i Adapter

This kit makes it easy to mount the Rev Through Bore Encoder to the SDS MK4i Swerve Modules. Included Components:2 - 8-32 x 1 in. Socket Head Cap Screw (am-1722)2 - 10-32 x 0.5 in. Button Head Cap Screw (am-1512)1 - 8-32 x 0.5 in. Button Head Cap...

We have used TTB encoders for a couple years now, we had a couple die last year but we were all good this season so it was likely somehow our implementation. I can definitely recommend them, we moved from CTRE CANcoders (which we ran on MK4s in 2022). Definitely hot glue connectors if you use them though.

I didnâ€™t know REV had an adapter either but their encoders are really good so Iâ€™ll have to look at that for next yearâ€¦

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-05-17T02:04:22.324Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":250,"readers_count":249,"score":50.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":466401,"topic_slug":"swerve-encoder-options","display_username":"Sean","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58253,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2220 Captain"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-encoder-options/466401/4","custom_user_title":"2220 Captain","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3387506,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-17T04:30:09.209Z","cooked":"

if youâ€™re a cheapskate like me, and donâ€™t mind soldering and pronting your own cases, you can use these AMS breakout boards, they produce a duty cycle output which is better than the voltage output of some other options. the new vortex motor can use this signal directly for position control.

ams-osram

ams AS5048A_TS_EVM_AB Evaluation board Boards - ams-osram - ams

The AS5048A (SPI-Version) Adapter Board allows you an easy-to-use evaluation of the principle function of the AS5048A magnetic position sensor in your own system design. This small factor board includes the position sensor with its necessary external...

weâ€™ve also used thriftybot, they work well, plug and play.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-05-17T05:55:14.095Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":223,"readers_count":222,"score":49.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":466401,"topic_slug":"swerve-encoder-options","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://ams-osram.com/products/boards-kits-accessories/boards/ams-as5048a-ts-evm-ab-evaluation-board","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"ams AS5048A_TS_EVM_AB Evaluation board Boards | ams OSRAM","clicks":10}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/swerve-encoder-options/466401/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3387530,"name":"Anand Rajamani","username":"asid61","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/asid61/{size}/7179_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-17T06:16:21.974Z","cooked":"

Note that the AS5048 only provides a wonky PWM output, so youâ€™ll need to do some math to decode it properly.

Screenshot_20240516_2313501080Ã—1140 89.5 KB

The more useful AS5145B will provide a 0.1-99.9% duty cycle that is easily decoded with the DutyCycleEncoder class on the RoboRIO.

The Canandcoder provides both CAN and PWM output.

tbh if i were in your situation I would just go with the Helium Canandcoders, theyâ€™re pretty cheap, very straightforward to use, and very reliable. They also reduce the wiring hassle especially if you are using neos.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-05-17T08:16:09.728Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":181,"readers_count":180,"score":111.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":466401,"topic_slug":"swerve-encoder-options","display_username":"Calvin Hou","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59620,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"miso #TeamWCP ðŸ˜¼"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-encoder-options/466401/7","custom_user_title":"miso #TeamWCP ðŸ˜¼","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3387616,"name":"Emerson OHara","username":"Emerson1706","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/emerson1706/{size}/174702_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-17T14:19:23.933Z","cooked":"

FWIW, we used NEOs for Azimuth and were able to use Canandencoders with PWM directly to the sparkmax, this allowed the entire azimuth close loop control to be contained to the sparkmax, simplifying wiring and code. We have also used TTB analog encoders and seeded the sparkmax value on code startup. Iâ€™ve found better results with the former directly closing the loop on the encoder as backlash will not effect the readings.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-05-17T14:19:47.840Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":154,"readers_count":153,"score":50.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":466401,"topic_slug":"swerve-encoder-options","display_username":"Emerson OHara","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":43759,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1706 Drive Coach | 9401 Mentor | #TeamThrifty"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-encoder-options/466401/8","custom_user_title":"1706 Drive Coach | 9401 Mentor | #TeamThrifty","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3387682,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-17T16:21:06.441Z","cooked":"
asid61:

The more useful AS5145B will provide a 0.1-99.9% duty cycle that is easily decoded with the DutyCycleEncoder class on the RoboRIO.

thank you, youâ€™re right.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-05-17T16:21:06.441Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":125,"readers_count":124,"score":30.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":466401,"topic_slug":"swerve-encoder-options","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/swerve-encoder-options/466401/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3387706,"name":"viggy96","username":"viggy96","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/viggy96/{size}/252784_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-17T17:04:21.618Z","cooked":"

If NEOS are being used for module rotation, then the through bore encoder with adapters seems like the cleanest option. Then you can get the absolute encoder adapters for the Spark Max, and just plug the encoder straight in.

The Canandcoder seems just about as simple. Youâ€™ll just have to solder to a data breakout adapter board on the Spark Max.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-05-17T17:04:21.618Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":111,"readers_count":110,"score":32.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":466401,"topic_slug":"swerve-encoder-options","display_username":"viggy96","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24613,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"418 Mentor | Tries to be smart"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-encoder-options/466401/10","custom_user_title":"418 Mentor | Tries to be smart","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3387742,"name":"Anand Rajamani","username":"asid61","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/asid61/{size}/7179_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-17T17:59:25.465Z","cooked":"

The Canandcoder plugs into a Spark MAX directly with no modifications fwiw.
